summary: A letter written in 2011 by former U.S. Attorney R. Alexander Acosta, providing his perspective on the federal prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein. He details the aggressive defense strategy mounted by Epstein's legal team, the prosecution's insistence on a plea deal requiring jail time and sex offender registration, and his justification for the final outcome based on the evidence known at the time.

events.title: State Attorney's Initial Charging Decision
events.description: The Palm Beach County State Attorney agreed to charge Epstein only with one count of aggravated assault with no intent to commit a felony, which would have resulted in no jail time or sex offender registration.

events.title: Initial Prosecution Meeting with Defense
events.description: Federal prosecutors and agents met with Epstein's attorney, Roy Black, and presented Epstein a choice: plead to more serious state felony charges (2 years imprisonment, registration, restitution) or face a federal felony trial.

events.title: Defense Team Meeting with U.S. Attorney
events.description: The defense team met with U.S. Attorney Acosta and the prosecution team in Fall 2007 to challenge the prosecution; Acosta reaffirmed the office's position on the plea terms.

events.title: Epstein's Guilty Plea
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pled guilty in state court to serve 18 months imprisonment, register as a sexual offender for life, and provide restitution to the victims.

events.title: Epstein's Unusual Jail Treatment
events.description: Epstein received highly unusual treatment while in state custody, which, according to Acosta, undermined the purpose of a jail sentence.

keyFacts: Former U.S. Attorney R. Alexander Acosta states that Epstein's defense team was the most aggressive he or his prosecutors had ever encountered, employing tactics like investigating prosecutors' families and repeatedly appealing to Washington.

The prosecution's consistent position was that Epstein must plead to state felony charges resulting in 2 years imprisonment, sex offender registration, and victim restitution, or face a federal trial.

Acosta acknowledges that evidence which came to light after 2007 (victim statements, physical evidence) might have changed the outcome, but the prosecution decision was based on admissible facts known at the time.
Epstein's defense team included high-profile attorneys Roy Black, Alan Dershowitz, Kenneth Starr, and Jay Lefkowitz, and also included former federal prosecutors.

Acosta defends the final plea deal, arguing it was better to secure a guaranteed sentence for a billionaire than risk a trial with a reduced likelihood of success based on the evidence then available.
